awd_titl_txt: Precision Theory at the LHC: Strong Interaction Dynamics and New Physics Searches
awd_abstract_narration:
This award funds the research activity of Professor Marco Guzzi at Kennesaw State University. 

The CERN Large Hadron Collider (LHC) is the world's biggest and most powerful particle accelerator where high energy beams of protons, traveling at approximately the speed of light, collide.  Accurate measurements from the LHC experiments brought high-energy physics to a new realm of precision that allows us to deepen our knowledge of the structure of matter and its elementary constituents and to shed light on possible new physics interactions.  This field of research is vibrant and its rapid progress is of high importance for the national interest as it promotes advances of fundamental science that are crucial for new discoveries. Theoretical and experimental analyses at the unprecedented energies of the LHC demand precision.  This is essential for meaningful comparisons between theory and experiment and a correct interpretation of the results.  In his research, Professor Guzzi aims to calculate precise theoretical predictions and use efficient methods for phenomenology to improve our current knowledge of the structure of the proton and set stringent tests on the Standard Model of the elementary particles, as well as search for new particle signatures predicted by theories of new physics.  The proposed research also has significant broader impacts:  Professor Guzzi will involve students in his research, give public lectures on his research results, and develop new course curricula based on the results of his research.

On the technical side, Professor Guzzi will use precise theory predictions for kinematic distributions of top-quark pairs produced at the LHC to reduce the uncertainties associated with parton distribution functions (PDF's). PDF's of the proton map out the longitudinal momentum distribution of its constituent quarks and gluons and they are a crucial limiting factor in the accuracy of theoretical predictions for many important observables at the LHC. A second part of the proposed project aims to improve the theory predictions for searches for extra neutral vector bosons at the LHC, generically referred to as Z' bosons. They differ from the Standard-Model Z boson by having different masses and couplings. With the improvements of the proton PDF's discussed above and with new precise measurements of dilepton pair production in Drell-Yan processes at LHC Run-II energies and luminosities, Professor Guzzi will study the parameter space of Z's of generic origin and will scrutinize a large number of new physics models. Finally, Professor Guzzi will determine with high precision the nonperturbative parameters of the transverse momentum dependent (TMD) distributions of the proton by using high-order perturbation theory and recent precise LHC measurements for Z-boson production in terms of a novel angular variable that has the advantage of being very sensitive to nonperturbative effects. TMD distributions represent the ultimate frontier of factorization theorems in QCD and allow us to have a unified framework in which to describe hadronic reactions in different energy regimes.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
In the past three years, the High Energy Physics program at the CERN Large Hadron Collider (LHC) has progressed at fast pace. Several precision calculations to determine standard candle observables at the LHC run I and II were accomplished and were confronted with high-precision LHC measurements. This allowed us to extract vital information that deepened our knowledge of the Standard Model of Elementary Particles and advanced our understanding of the structure of the proton and of its inner constituents quarks and gluons.

The NSF funded research ``Precision Theory at the LHC: Strong interaction dynamics and new Physics searches'' (NSF Grant no. PHY-1820818) of Dr. Guzzi at Kennesaaw State University (KSU) has contributed to this advancement during the 3-year life of the award through various project outcomes.

Dr. Guzzi contributed to determine new parton distribution functions (PDFs) of the proton named CT18 PDFs. PDFs of the proton map out the longitudinal momentum distribution of its constituent quarks and gluons. PDFs are a crucial limiting factor in the accuracy of theoretical predictions for many important observables at the LHC. The CT18 analysis (Phys.Rev.D 103 014013 (2021)) uses precision data from the LHC and other experiments together with high-precision theory calculations which constrain proton PDFs. In addition, CT18 PDFs are a necessary ingredient for transverse momentum dependent (TMD) distribution functions. In fact, they are used as an input in many theory calculations with transverse momentum resummation. The CT18 publication has already more than 180 citations which is proof of the high impact of this work.

Dr. Guzzi contributed to the progress of new physics interaction searches. In particular, he calculated theory predictions at high order in perturbation theory to predict the production of extra neutral vector bosons at the LHC, generically referred to as Z′ bosons. Z′s differ from the Standard Model (SM) neutral vector boson, known as the Z boson, by having different mass and coupling. The study of the parameter space for Z′ interactions is critical to validate new physics models through new precise measurements at the LHC and future colliders. Dr. Guzzi accomplished the analysis for the production of a single top-quark in association with an extra Z′ at hadron colliders (Eur. Phys. Jour. C 80, 5. (2020)). He used high-precision theory predictions at in Quantum Chromodynamics (QCD) based on threshold expansions beyond the leading logarithmic approximation to explore the parameter space of different Z′ models. This work was done in collaboration with Prof. N. Kidonakis at KSU and it demonstrates the synergistic work of the partcle theory group.

Dr. Guzzi contributed to advance the theoretical understanding of substructure of QCD jets. A QCD jet is an energy deposit in hadron collider detectors which appears as a narrow cone of hadrons and other particles produced by the hadronization of quarks or gluons. Quarks and gluons are copiously produced in reactions at the LHC. The development of analytical methods to understand the substructure of jets in QCD is important because it provides insights for the investigation of the logarithmic structure of jet mass distributions in direct connection to the QCD matrix elements in the collinear limit and beyond. This is critical for precision calculations of QCD jet observables, for background/signal discrimination, and new physics searches at hadron colliders. Dr. Guzzi investigated the link between parton dynamics in the collinear limit and the logarithmically enhanced terms of jet mass distributions (Eur. Phys. Jour. C. 80, 9 (2020)). He contributed to compute higher order logarithmic terms for quark initiated jets, using triple-collinear splitting functions. This work was done in collaboration with the particle theory group at Manchester University in the UK.

The outcomes of this NSF grant were presented by Dr. Guzzi in several international conferences in the US and in Europe: CIPANP2018, QCD@work2018, DIS2019, DIS2021, DPF2021, PHENO2021, Forward Physics Facilities Workshop, SnowMass2021. Conference proceedings for these conferences have also been published. In addition, Dr. Guzzi submitted a letter of intent for the SnowMass2020/2021 activities, which aims to advance our current understanding of heavy-flavor PDFs.

As broader impacts, Dr. Guzzi's NSF funded research provided opportunities for research and teaching in the field of theoretical particle physics and hadron collider phenomenology. He was invited as a speaker at the annual CTEQ2019 Summer School and as a visiting scientist for 2 months at University of Salento in Italy, to give lectures in quantum field theory. 

Dr. Guzzi supervised undergraduate students at KSU who were hired as research assistants and supported by this NSF grant. Moreover, Guzzi mentored high-school students during internships concerning with basic concepts of QCD and hadron collider phenomenology.

Because of his achievements in Research, Teaching, and Service activity at Kennesaw State University, Dr. Guzzi received the ``Outstanding Early Career Faculty Award'' in 2021. This NSF grant was essential to achieve this result.
